Chongqing Institute of Green and Intelligent Technology Chinese Academy of Sciences Fangzheng Avenue 266# Chongqing 400714 PR China The present study demonstrates an innovative approach of doping MnCeO x /GR catalyst with three transition metal ions, namely Fe3+, Co3+, and Ni2+. Subsequently, the catalyst exhibiting superior performance was carefully selected. Meanwhile, the micro-reaction process of MnCeO x /GR and ion-doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts were established by in situ DRIFTS. The phenomena occurred in the experiment process were thoroughly examined through the application of various characteristic analysis, for instance, XRD, Raman, BET, XPS, H2-TPR, and NH3-TPD to analyze that Co3+ doping had a good improvement of activity and N2 selectivity on MnCeO x /GR catalyst at low temperature. This was evidenced by the activity test experiments, which revealed that CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst has the highest NO conversion within 150–225 °C temperature range, surpassing 90 %. Our findings showed that Co3+ doping not only enhanced redox capability and surface acidity, but also raised the relative Mn4+, Ce3+, and Oα content compared to MnCeO x /GR catalyst, which eventually contributed that the reactant molecules can be more effectively adsorbed onto the catalyst, thereby enhancing activation of NH3 and O2, thus improving efficiency of CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst. Additionally, it was proved that the Eley-Rideal and Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanisms co-existed on CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst in a competitive way by in situ DRIFTS test. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MnCeOx catalyst Ion doping Graphene Low-temperature denitrification NH3-SCR reaction 1 Introduction With the acceleration of our country's industrialization process, NO x , as an important component of flue gas, seriously harms the atmospheric environment and human health. Selective catalytic reduction of NO x by NH3 (NH3-SCR) technology is regarded as a cost-effective and triumphant approach to diminishing NO x from stationary sources and mobile sources through catalytic reduction [1]. V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst has excellent denitrification performance and outstanding SO2 resistance during the optimal temperature range of 300–420 °C [2], which are used extensively in NH3-SCR reaction [3]. In spite of this, the main issue in the practical industrial application lies in the excessively low-temperature flue gas, which can't adapt to the required temperature zone for NH3-SCR denitrification. Simultaneously, the biotoxicity and volatility of V2O5, along with the harmfulness of waste catalyst to the environment, impose limitations on its extensive application [4,5]. In this case, the low-temperature denitrification catalyst not only exhibits exceptional performance, but also possesses a broad operating temperature range, thereby showcasing its potential for diverse industrial applications. Therefore, the development of catalysts exhibiting high catalytic performance and N2 selectivity at low temperatures, while posing no harm to the environment, is an indispensable stride towards NO x treatment and industrialization advancement. The NH3-SCR technology has consistently been a prominent area of research in the realm of green and sustainable technology. Namely, the flue gas is subjected to a selective reduction of NO x to clean N2 under specific aerobic conditions, with the aid of catalysts, by introducing NH3 as a reducing agent. The catalyst, which is often comprised of various metal oxides, garners significant attention as a pivotal component in the NH3-SCR technology, such as MnO x , CuO, CrO x , CoO x , FeO x , CeO2, NiO and WO3 [6–12]. Among them, the manganese-based catalysts has remarkable low temperature denitrification performance due to its multivalent state of Mn species and high mobility of surface chemisorbed oxygen [13]. Cerium, meanwhile, has been given consideration due to its remarkable oxygen storage capacity. However, both pure CeO2 and pure MnO x have unfavorable low-temperature catalytic activity and N2 selectivity, which has become a problem that we have to face and need to solve [14,15]. Surprisingly, after MnO x modification, the NO x removal efficiency and N2 selectivity of CeO2 are effectively increased at low temperature. Thus, many interesting conclusions about the amalgamation of CeO2 and MnO x has been revealed by researchers. Kim et al. [16] observed that the Mn-Ce/TiO2 co-initiated catalyst had a much more impressive NO conversion ratio than other catalysts. Chen et al. [17] developed a high activity low-temperature Ce@Mn catalyst (MnO x coated cubic CeO2) within 100–300 °C. Zhao et al. [18] reported a core-shell Ce0.2Mn0.2/FeVO4 catalyst that exhibited remarkable 90 % NO x conversion and a good tolerance to H2O and SO2. Results of these experiments demonstrate that MnCeO x catalysts deserve more research in the field of low temperature denitrification. Additionally, catalyst carrier also has a subtle impact on the activity of catalysts. Metal oxide nanoparticles can be prone to sintering during the reaction, further diminishing their catalytic capacity. The support in catalysts could positively enhance the thermal stability of nanoparticles and promoting the dispersion of active components, thus underscoring its indispensability for achieving optimal dispersion of metal oxide catalysts. Graphene, a new kind of green material [19,20], appears to be a promising support to improve NH3-SCR performance of catalysts [21]. The two-dimensional material graphene possesses exceptional properties such as high conductivity, large specific surface area, and remarkable chemical and mechanical stability [19]. Besides, its ability to efficiently promote electron migration between catalyst components facilitates the redox performance of the catalysts. Recent accounts have shown the capacity of MnCeO x /GR catalyst to boost the diffusion of the active phase through graphene support on account of its strong stability and electron transfer capacity [22–25]. Nevertheless, numerous researchers have also achieved remarkable outcomes in the realm of metal oxide catalysts supported by graphene, demonstrating exceptional resistance to H2O and SO2. Yet the problem that catalytic activity of MnCeO x /GR is unsatisfactory at low temperature, suggesting that there is still a pressing need to enhance NO removal rate and N2 selectivity below 300 °C. Ion doping is widely employed to enhance catalysts' efficacy [26–30]. The chemical properties of Fe3+, Co3+, and Ni2+ are similar, making them commonly utilized as low-temperature dopants in NH3-SCR catalysts. The introduction of Fe3+, as reported by Yang et al. [31], not only enhanced the conversion of NO, but also augmented the H2O and SO2 resistance of MnTiO x catalyst. Co3+, with its remarkable redox ability and straightforward morphology control, has been employed in many catalysis study [32]. Moreover, earlier research has revealed that the benefits of Co3+ doping in enhancing the N2 selectivity of ZSM-5 impregnated with Mn species [33], and Ni2+ doping maintained MnNi2O4 catalyst keep a significantly commendable catalytic activity, as Gao et al. discovered [34]. Additionally, the use of graphene as a carrier for metal oxide catalysts has been broadly researched, however, limited attention has been given to the impact of transition metal ions (Fe3+, Co3+, Ni2+) on the MnCeO x /GR catalysis system. We thus endeavor to augment the ability of NO transfer to N2 of MnCeO x /GR catalyst at low temperature extent. This study enhanced the dispersibility of MnCeO x on the graphene support, as well as introducing representative metal ions Me (Me = Fe3+, Co3+, Ni2+) to improve the NH3-SCR activity and N2 selectivity. The effect of Fe3+, Co3+, Ni2+ on the surface texture properties and internal electronic interactions of MnCeO x /GR were also assessed through a variety of characterizations. And the microscopic changes and underlying mechanism of active intermediates formation and conversion course during catalysis process were investigated through in situ DRIFTS experiments. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalytic performance measurements A SCR catalytic evaluation device (Model: SCR-6F) was used to access catalysts’ activity. The gas concentration in the reactor was showed by FGA10 (flue gas analyzer, produced by Beit Technology Co, Ltd, China) and G200 (N2O analyzer, produced by Bedfont Scientific Ltd, England. More particular devices information is shown in the supported information. 2.2 Materials and preparation methods Specific preparation information of all catalysts is showed in the supported information. 2.3 Catalytic characterization methods The characterization techniques employed for the catalysts, including XRD, Raman spectroscopy, BET analysis, H2-TPR measurement, etc., are comprehensively elucidated in the supported information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity and N2 selectivity for NH3-SCR The trend of NO conversion of MnCeO x /GR and ion-doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts with temperature in the 75–275 °C range is illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). It was evident that the high activity zone of MnCeO x /GR catalyst was mainly located between 150 and 275 °C, yet the NO conversion was less than 90 %. Fe3+ doping had no discernible impact on MnCeO x /GR. Ni2+ doping, however, decreased the activity of MnCeO x /GR within 150–275 °C. For Co3+ doped-MnCeO x /GR catalyst, it was demonstrated the most impressive denitrification activity temperature range was within 75–250 °C, and its NO conversion reached 93 % at 225 °C, which was higher than that of the other three catalysts. Moreover, CoMnCeO x /GR exhibited 75 % NO conversion at 100 °C, which showed a great increase of 24 % compared with that of MnCeO x /GR (57 %). These results demonstrated an impressive enhancement in the low-temperature conversion of NO on the MnCeO x /GR catalyst through Co3+ doping, while the operating window were simultaneously expanded. Considering the fact that in practical low-temperature NH3-SCR applications, the catalysts containing MnO x would lead to a significant generation of N2O byproducts via non-selective catalytic oxidation of NH3, thereby severely compromising the N2 selectivity [35]. Therefore, reducing N2O production is beneficial for enhancing the N2 selectivity of catalyst. Fig. 1(b) shows the N2O concentration generated during the activity test. The N2O concentration of ion-doped catalysts were evidently less than that of MnCeO x /GR catalyst in the 150–250 °C range. This result indicated that Fe3+, Co3+ and Ni2+ doping can effectively enhance the N2 selectivity of MnCeO x /GR catalyst within 150–250 °C. Moreover, CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst exhibited the most impressive performance, with a much lower concentration of N2O than that of MnCeO x /GR at 200–275 °C at the same time. This can be attributed to that Co3+-doped metal oxide catalyst may exhibit enhanced catalytic activity, owing to the synergistic effect of Co species with other various metal elements (Mn and Ce species), which enhances the reducibility of the catalyst and promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies [10]. These oxygen vacancies play a crucial role in accelerating N2O dissociation [11]. Additionally, it can be observed that NiMnCeO x /GR catalyst generated the least amount of N2O, this may be attributed to the poor redox ability for NiMnCeO x /GR sample (supported by H2-TPR results), which lead to the active components on NiMnCeO x /GR catalyst even could not reduce NO to N2 efficiently, and the catalytic oxidation of NH3 to N2O is subject to inhibition, thereby it does not meet the criteria for producing additional N2O. To sum up, Fe3+ and Ni2+ doping could impede the N2O formation on MnCeO x /GR during the NH3-SCR reaction, yet could not enhance its NH3-SCR activity. However, Co3+ doping could improve the denitrification activity but also N2 selectivity below 300 °C, further expanding the operating window of MnCeO x /GR catalyst. 3.2 Structural properties (XRD, Raman, BET and TEM) Fig. 2 displays the crystal structure properties of each catalyst. Only cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 diffraction peaks [PDF-ICDD 43–1002] was observed on the MnCeO x /GR catalyst. However, compared with CeO2 PDF-ICCD, the diffraction peaks of MnCeO x /GR slightly shifted to a higher-angle direction, this may due to that Mn4+ incorporation into the CeO2 lattice to form Mn-O-Ce solid solution, resulting in lattice shrinkage (Mn4+ ionic radius (0.54 Å) is smaller than that of Ce4+ (0.92 Å)) [15]. This further explains the presence of Mn-O-Ce solid solution structure, agree with the literature [36]. No changes in CeO2 crystal composition were observed after any ions doping apart from the peak intensity. The peak intensities of FeMnCeO x /GR and CoMnCeO x /GR catalysts weakened slightly compared with MnCeO x /GR, whereas that of NiMnCeO x /GR catalyst exhibited an opposite change trend. The grain size of the catalysts can be analyzed by utilizing the Debye-Scherrer equation [37], it was discovered that the mean crystalline sizes of MnCeO x /GR, FeMnCeO x /GR, CoMnCeO x /GR and NiMnCeO x /GR catalysts are around 4.8, 4.2, 4.5, and 5.6 nm, respectively, and diffraction peaks corresponding to metal ion-doped oxides are absent. These phenomena indicated that both of Fe3+ (0.65 Å) and Co3+ (0.63 Å) were incorporated into the CeO2 lattice resoundingly and further decrease the crystalline size, while the introduction of Ni2+ may facilitate the enlargement of grain size or the accumulated aggregation of metal oxides. Raman spectroscopy test was conducted on each catalyst to further validate the XRD findings, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . The vibration peak at 460 cm−1 belonged to CeO2 cubic structure (F2g) was observed on each catalyst [38]. The F2g peak intensity of MnCeO x /GR catalyst was significantly reduced when Fe3+ and Co3+ were added, and the FWHM (full width at half maximum) broadened, implying a decline in CeO2 crystalline size. Additionally, the peak at 598 cm−1 is linked to oxygen vacancies (labeled as D) [39,40]. In other word, this was given to the oxygen vacancies formed by the introduction of doped ions at Ce4+ sites, thereby sustaining the charge balance, explained by vacancy compensation mechanism [41,42]. Besides, the Mn-O peak, in the vicinity of the 650 cm−1 band, was also visible, while the intensity of this peak on the NiMnCeO x /GR catalyst was markedly greater, implying that the presence of Ni2+ dopants impedes the formation of Mn-O-Ce solid solution and increases the crystallization of MnO x extremely, thereby bringing out the compromised performance of NiMnCeO x /GR. The specific morphological structure of each catalyst can be observed using a typical transmission electron microscope. The results were shown in Fig. 4 . Obviously, all catalysts were dispersed relatively uniformly with irregular morphology. The lattice fringe spacing of each catalyst being 0.32 nm implied that the CeO2 mainly exposed {111} facet on each catalyst, and the transition metal ion doping had no effect on the exposed crystal plane of MnCeO x /GR catalyst. Furthermore, no streaks other species were detected, implying that the doped ions had been introduced into the CeO2 lattice successfully, which was consistent with XRD and Raman results. Meanwhile, Fe3+, Co3+ and Ni2+ species were dispersed in a uniform way over all the ion-doped catalysts (the EDS mapping scan in Fig. S1). Table 1 reveals the textural state of MnCeO x /GR and ions doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts and displays their porosities conditions in turn. The investigations from researchers evince that there is a positive influence between the specific surface area and the dispersion of the catalyst's active ingredients, manifesting that a larger specific surface area contributes to disperse more active sites evenly. And the larger total pore volume is not only advantageous to the full contact between reactants and catalysts, but also helpful to the diffusion of reactant molecules, thus augmenting NH3-SCR performance [43]. The specific surface area of these catalysts followed the sequence of FeMnCeO x /GR > MnCeO x /GR > CoMnCeO x /GR > NiMnCeO x /GR. However, the performances of FeMnCeO x /GR and MnCeO x /GR catalysts at low temperature were worse than that of CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst, which proved that there are truly other undiscovered aspects affecting the catalysts’ denitrification performance than the BET specific surface area. 3.3 Redox performance and surface acidity (H2-TPR, NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption) The H2-TPR demonstrates the reducibility of MnCeO x /GR, FeMnCeO x /GR, CoMnCeO x /GR, and NiMnCeO x /GR catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 5 . The three reduction peaks ranging from 200 to 400 °C (I, II, and III), were brought about by the gradual reduction of MnO2→Mn2O3, then Mn2O3→Mn3O4, finally Mn3O4→MnO and the surface Ce4+ reduction [44,45]. Compared with MnCeO x /GR catalyst, the reduction peak of Fe3+ in FeMnCeO x /GR catalyst appeared at 338 °C (Fe2O3→Fe3O4), mainly overlapped by peak II. The reduction peak of Co3+ in CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst appeared at 330–380 °C (Co3+→Co2+ and Co2+→Co0), overlapped by peak III [46,47]. The remarkable lower peak temperature of CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst compared to MnCeO x /GR catalyst implies that Mn species in CoMnCeO x /GR are simpler to reduce. This is mainly due to the improvement of electron transfer on the surface of MnCeO x /GR by Co3+ doping, which can boost oxygen mobility or activate reactants in NH3-SCR reaction. Additionally, the catalyst's catalytic capacity is intricately linked to its reduction property in NH3-SCR reaction process [48,49]. Therefore, Table 2 summarized the H2 consumption data of synthesized catalysts, followed by CoMnCeO x /GR > MnCeO x /GR ≈ FeMnCeO x /GR > NiMnCeO x /GR. On the basis of XRD findings, we inferred that the incorporation of Co3+ into CeO2 lattice generated uniform -Ce-O-Mn-O-Co- solid solution, which can promote the electron transfer and improve the redox performance, thus resulting in the best deNO x performance of CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst. NH3-TPD was utilized to determine the quantity and relative strength of acidic sites in catalysts, with the aim of elucidating the impact of surface acidity on deNO x catalyst activity [50]. Consequently, it can be used as a pivotal criterion for assessing the efficacy of catalysts. Fig. 6 and Table 3 show the situation of surface acidity of MnCeO x /GR and ion-doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts. For MnCeO x /GR and FeMnCeO x /GR samples, three desorption peaks can be observed from 100 to 600 °C, which were labelled as I, II, and III, respectively. The peak I is linked to the weakly adsorbed NH3; peaks II is the medium acid sites; and peak III is identified as the potent acid sites [51]. A new potent acid site (peak IV) was observed over CoMnCeO x /GR and NiMnCeO x /GR specimens [4]. It is closely interconnected between the NH3 adsorption peak temperature and the acid site strength in catalyst, also, NH3 desorption peak area also means the catalysts’ acid sites quantities [52]. The information presented in Table 3 demonstrates that the positions of peaks II and III over CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst shifted to a higher temperature direction compared with other catalysts. This result stated that Co3+ doping improves acid sites strength of MnCeO x /GR catalyst. In comparison to the other three catalysts, the total acid amount of CoMnCeO x /GR is especially remarkable. This order of total acid amount (CoMnCeO x /GR > MnCeO x /GR > FeMnCeO x /GR > NiMnCeO x /GR) maintains consistency with the NH3-SCR performance outcome, indicating that CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst exhibited strengthened NH3 molecule adsorption capacity, thus promoting the NH3-SCR reaction. Precisely because of this, CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst could be credited with the most remarkable NH3-SCR activity below 300 °C. The type of acid site on the catalyst surface was investigated through in situ DRIFTS method for NH3 adsorption. Several peaks in the range of 1000–2000 cm−1 can be seen on MnCeO x /GR sample. For Fig. 7 (a), the bands at 1162, 1263 and 1590 cm−1 are assigned to NH bonds in NH3, coordinating with Lewis acid sites, as well as the band at 1419 cm−1 is supposed to be the NH4 +, associated with Brønsted acid sites [53–55]. The peak intensity of B acid (1419 cm−1) was gradually weakened with temperature increasing. However, the peak intensity of L acid (1419 cm−1) still remained strong within 175–300 °C, implying that L acid displays more superior thermal stability than B acid. Fig. 7(b) and Fig. 7(d) displayed the spectra of FeMnCeO x /GR and NiMnCeO x /GR catalysts, respectively. The spectra of these two catalysts were similar to that of MnCeO x /GR catalyst. While, as to CoMnCeO x /GR in Fig. 7(c), the B acid was nearly imperceptible, indicating that the majority of B acid sites had been occupied by Co3+ ions [56]. Moreover, a new peak at 1246 cm−1 was considered as the adsorbed NH3 deformation species [57]. The excellent deNO x activity for CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst was suggested by the fact that the peak intensity of the L-acid site associated with 1136 cm−1 in CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst surpasses that of FeMnCeO x /GR and NiMnCeO x /GR at room temperature, indicating its ability to adsorb NH3 more effectively at lower temperatures and consequently activating a larger number of NH3 reactant molecules. The NH3-TPD test results presented in this paper also further support the presence of more acid sites in CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst at low temperatures, which aligns with the findings from the NH3 in situ DIRFTS test, indicating that Co3+ doping can promote adsorption of NH3, thereby contributing to the good catalyst performance. 3.4 Surface component and chemical states (XPS) XPS technological means was employed to probe into the element valence states over MnCeO x /GR catalyst surface before and after Fe3+, Co3+ and Ni2+ doping. Fig. 8 provided the XPS results. As we can see in Fig. 8(a), Ce 3d spectra could be separated into 8 bands, tagged as u′′′, u′′, u′, u, v′′′, v′′, v′ and v. In which, the six peaks marked u′′′, u′′, u, v′′′, v′′, and v were represented Ce4+ ions, while the two peaks, u′ and v′, are Ce3+ ions, respectively [58,59]. Table 4 displays the Ce3+ ratio of these samples, calculated by Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+). The Ce3+ ratio of ion-doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts was higher than that on MnCeO x /GR catalyst, excluding NiMnCeO x /GR, which was consistent with the NO conversion outcomes. This is mainly due to the formation of Fe-O-Ce and Co-O-Ce solid structure when Fe3+ and Co3+ introduced. Generally, the Ce3+ content is of critical importance in determining the oxygen vacancies, further the formation of oxygen vacancies is also associated with the catalysts’ denitrification performance. The more oxygen vacancies produced, the more advantageous to boost the deNO x performance [60]. The remarkable Ce3+ content of CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst implied that the Co, Mn, and Ce species possess a strong interaction between electrons, thereby forming more catalytic active sites, then the reactants of NO, NH3 and O2 are fully adsorbed and activated, thus improving the NH3-SCR performance of CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst below 300 °C. Fig. 8(b) shows the XPS of O 1 s spectra on MnCeO x /GR and ion-doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts. The band situated at 529.6 eV is related to lattice oxygen (Oβ); The other band at 531.6 eV is ascribed to surface-adsorbed oxygen (Oα), existing as O2 2− or O−, which is attributed to oxidation defect [60]. Table 4 reveals the calculated Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio, the order is consistent with that of Ce3+ ratio. It was apparent that the relative surface-adsorbed oxygen Oα content has a substantial increase after Co3+ doping. The mobility of Oα is better than that of Oβ, which effectively promotes the oxidation of NO to NO2, thereby enhancing the performance of the "fast NH3-SCR" reaction on the CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst [61,62]. It is generally believed that, when NO2 is present in the reaction atmosphere, NH3 will react with both NO2 and NO simultaneously to produce N2 and H2O at an accelerated rate compared to when NO2 is absent, the reaction process is as follows in Eqs. (1): (1) NO + N O 2 + 2 N H 3 → 2 N 2 + 3 H 2 O Fig. 8(c) displays the spectra of Mn 2p3/2 on these catalysts. It can be accurately separated into three distinct signals at 640.8–641.1 eV, 642.3–642.4 eV and 643.5–643.9 eV, corresponding to Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively [63–65]. The relative content of Mn4+ on the surface of MnCeO x /GR samples is presented in Table 4. Previous reports found that Mn4+ contributes to the oxygen vacancies formation in MnCeO x catalyst [66]. The relative Mn4+ content was in the order of NiMnCeO x /GR < MnCeO x /GR < FeMnCeO x /GR < CoMnCeO x /GR. Interestingly, CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst unveiled the largest contents of Mn4+, the possible reason is that the occurrence of electron transfer among Co, Mn and Ce species may favor the increase of Mn4+. The XPS results of Fe 2p, Co 2p and Ni 2p in these doped-MnCeO x /GR samples are shown in Fig. 8(d). FeMnCeO x /GR catalyst showed that the peaks at 711.1 and 715.3 eV were ascribed to Fe2+ and Fe3+, respectively [67]. The peaks ascribed to Co3+ and Co2+ in CoMnCeO x /GR were at 780.9 and 779.6 eV, while the peaks of Ni2+ and Ni3+ in NiMnCeO x /GR were at 854.9 and 861.8 eV, respectively [68–70]. It can be determined that Fe, Co, and Ni elements exists in numerous valence states, which is advantageous to the redox cycle among the metal elements of these ion-doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts [71]. The introduction of Co3+ has been widely acknowledged to augment the surface Ce3+ proportion and surface adsorbed oxygen in catalyst [12,71,72]. Hence, the NH3-SCR catalytic reaction has been substantially augmented by Co3+ doping for CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst, which produce more vigorous oxygen vacancies and improve the reversible redox cycles (Mn3+ + Ce4+ ↔ Mn4+ + Ce3+, Mn3+ + Co3+ ↔ Mn4+ + Co2+ and Co2+ + Ce4+ ↔ Co3+ + Ce3+), thus facilitating the NO removal ultimately [72]. 3.5 Surface adsorbed species study (in situ DRIFTS of NO + O2 adsorption and NO + NH3 + O2 co-adsorption) Fig. 9 performs the results of in situ DRIFTS of NO + O2 adsorption and identifies the kinds of adsorbed reactants on the surfaces of MnCeO x /GR and ion-doped samples. For several infrared vibration bands at 1014, 1237, 1284, 1531, 1575 and 1605 cm−1 are detected when MnCeO x /GR catalyst is saturated by NO + O2 at 30 °C (Fig. 9(a)). The bands at 1014 and 1605 cm−1 are commonly recognized as bridging nitrates. Afterwards, the bands at 1237, 1284, and 1531 cm−1 correspond to monodentate nitrates [28,73]; also note that the band at 1575 cm−1 is bidentate nitrates [74]. The intensity of these adsorbed NO x species bands diminished slightly to a certain degree by thermal desorption and decomposition as the heat increases. Interestingly, the ion-doped catalysts gradually showed two new bands around at 1212 and 1533 cm−1 at higher temperatures, which are thought to be originated from bridging nitrates and monodentate nitrates [75]. In detail, there are some points of CoMnCeO x /GR which differs from that of other catalysts in several aspects: firstly, a new peak of bridging nitrates (1212 cm−1) emerged at 50 °C, and the peak intensity of this band intensified overtly as the temperature rose to 300 °C, while that of other ion-doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts did not change much with temperature rising. Secondly, a new peak vested in monodentate nitrates (1533 cm−1) also appeared at an earlier temperature (50 °C) in CoMnCeO x /GR compared with FeMnCeO x /GR (100 °C) and NiMnCeO x /GR (150 °C). In general, the monodentate nitrates and bridging nitrates are more active intermediate products than bidentate nitrate during the NH3-SCR process [76]. Hence, we infer that the introduction of Co3+ remarkably stimulated the formation of active nitrates species on CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst, especially monodentate nitrates and bridging nitrates, which might be the reason why CoMnCeO x /GR has the best deNO x performance. Moreover, for the sake of inquiry for dominant and concrete principles in the whole NH3-SCR reaction process, in situ DRIFTS tests for NO + NH3 + O2 adsorption were implemented. The consequences of NO + NH3 + O2 in situ DRIFTS over these MnCeO x /GR and ion-doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts are obtained in Fig. 10 . MnCeO x /GR catalyst (Fig. 10(a)) emerged several signals of bridging nitrates (1209, 1258 and 1615 cm−1), bidentate nitrates (1531 and 1563 cm−1) and the coordinated NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites (1157 cm−1) when the mixed gas was introduced at the room temperature (30 °C). These infrared vibration bands also appeared on FeMnCeO x /GR, CoMnCeO x /GR and NiMnCeO x /GR catalysts (Fig. 10(b-d)). For CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst, the signals of Lewis acid sites (1155 cm−1) are evidently stronger than that in NH3 adsorption in Fig. 7(c). This is due to the CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst's surface acidity is significantly increased by the adsorption of NO, an acidic oxide, thus further stimulating the adsorption of NH3 molecules. Noticeably, the peak intensity of L acid and other nitrates exhibited a more rapid decrease during heating process in comparison to other catalysts, indicating that the incorporation of Co3+ can immensely expedite the reaction process. In other word, the CoMnCeO x /GR exhibits simultaneous adsorption of NO and NH3, enabling concurrent reactions between adsorbed NH3 and adsorbed NO, illustrating that the presence of the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism is evident throughout the entire NH3-SCR reaction process. On the other hand, the bridging nitrates (1214 cm−1) came into being from 200 °C, and its intensity gradually strengthened with temperature elevating. Beyond that the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism was put forward in MnCeO x /GR and ion-doped catalysts, which is propped up by the secondary reaction (the reaction between adsorbed states reactants and gaseous reactants, Fig. S2 and Fig. S3 in the supported information). The evidence pointed that both L-H and E-R mechanisms were present on the MnCeO x /GR and ion-doped catalyst, with the former one (L-H mechanisms) being the dominant one. Fig. 11 displays a schematic representation of the NH3-SCR reaction process on CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst. The doping of Co3+ greatly improves the NO removal efficiency of MnCeO x /GR at low temperature, which can be believed to the following accounts: (1) The CeO2 lattice can be filled by Co3+ and Mnn+ species, producing a solid solution with -Co-O-Mn-O-Ce- structure. Furthermore, this occurrence is closely associated to the electron transformation of individual active components and redox cycle of CoMnCeO x /GR during NH3-SCR reaction (i.e., Mn3+ + Ce4+ ↔ Mn4+ + Ce3+, Mn3+ + Co3+ ↔ Mn4+ + Co2+ and Co2+ + Ce4+ ↔ Co3+ + Ce3+). (2) Co3+doped- MnCeO x /GR has the highest Ce3+, Mn4+ and surface-adsorbed oxygen content in these catalysts, and the content of acid sites and acid strength are also the most prominent, thus urging NH3 and NO to be adsorbed and activated. (3) Co3+ doping triggers the activation of NO x intermediates, like monodentate nitrates and bridging nitrates. In addition, Fig. 11 proves that when MnCeO x/GR and ion-doped catalysts unconcealed to NO + NH3 + O2 atmospheres, the active species NH3, NO, and O2 are adsorbed on the catalyst surfaces, leading to the occurrence of NH3-SCR reaction between the adsorbed reactants, namely adsorbed NH3 and adsorbed NO x . Moreover, the slow reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO + O2 species, as well as between gaseous NO + O2 and pre-adsorbed NH3 (Fig. S2 and Fig. S3 in the supported information) further bolsters that the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism is secondary. Consequently, Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism occurred on the surface of CoMnCeO x/GR catalyst is dominate. 4 Conclusion In summary, the low-temperature catalysts’ performance and N2 selectivity of MnCeO x /GR catalyst can be effectively enhanced by Co3+ doping, which can achieve more than 90 % NO conversion at 150–225 °C. The reasons are mainly that Co3+ doping can not only effectively reduces the grain size of MnCeO x /GR, so that the catalyst particles can fully contact the reactant molecules, but also enhances the surface acid strength of MnCeO x /GR and speeds up the redox cycle (Mn3+ + Ce4+ ↔ Mn4+ + Ce3+, Mn3+ + Co3+ ↔ Mn4+ + Co2+ and Co2+ + Ce4+ ↔ Co3+ + Ce3+), which obviously expedite the adsorption of NH3 species and intermediates formation like monodentate nitrates and bridging nitrates on the CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst. The findings of this study hold significant reference value for the design and development of Co3+-doped pollution-free low-temperature catalysts for NH3-SCR. coredata.dc:description: The present study demonstrates an innovative approach of doping MnCeO x /GR catalyst with three transition metal ions, namely Fe3+, Co3+, and Ni2+. Subsequently, the catalyst exhibiting superior performance was carefully selected. Meanwhile, the micro-reaction process of MnCeO x /GR and ion-doped MnCeO x /GR catalysts were established by in situ DRIFTS. The phenomena occurred in the experiment process were thoroughly examined through the application of various characteristic analysis, for instance, XRD, Raman, BET, XPS, H2-TPR, and NH3-TPD to analyze that Co3+ doping had a good improvement of activity and N2 selectivity on MnCeO x /GR catalyst at low temperature. This was evidenced by the activity test experiments, which revealed that CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst has the highest NO conversion within 150–225 °C temperature range, surpassing 90 %. Our findings showed that Co3+ doping not only enhanced redox capability and surface acidity, but also raised the relative Mn4+, Ce3+, and Oα content compared to MnCeO x /GR catalyst, which eventually contributed that the reactant molecules can be more effectively adsorbed onto the catalyst, thereby enhancing activation of NH3 and O2, thus improving efficiency of CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst. Additionally, it was proved that the Eley-Rideal and Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanisms co-existed on CoMnCeO x /GR catalyst in a competitive way by in situ DRIFTS test.
coredata.dc:title: In situ DRIFTS study and mechanism analysis of selective catalytic reduction of NO x by NH3 over ions doping MnCeO x /GR catalyst
